awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Ultrathin sheets on curved liquid surfaces: Stress focusing and interfacial assembly
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract

A mismatch in curvature between two surfaces is a common problem in nature and industry: flat bandages don't stick as well to curved knuckles or elbows, maps of the earth exaggerate areas near the poles, and automotive metal must be stamped or forged to make a curved fender. The project investigates such "geometric frustration" in a class of extremely bendable materials that are nonetheless hard to stretch, including ultrathin polymer films, textiles, and lightweight inflatable structures. The research investigates how the curvature of a liquid surface can propel thin polymer films, and how it can also wrinkle and crease them. The results will uncover new ways for controlling liquid interfaces by using flexible sheets, going beyond current methods using soap or solid particles. The research is coupled to a set of education and outreach projects that target a wide range of audiences. The project will train two PhD students, who will work with high school students and undergraduates in the lab. High-school teachers will also conduct research internships. A laboratory YouTube channel will be created, and an installation on wrinkling will be developed for the Museum of Science and Technology in downtown Syracuse, NY.

Technical Abstract

The project investigates the mechanical and geometrical behaviors of extremely bendable yet nearly inextensible sheets, a class of materials that includes ultrathin polymer films, textiles, and lightweight inflatable structures. First, curvature-driven assembly of thin polymer films on liquid surfaces is investigated. The energy landscape of an ultrathin sheet on a curved topography can be quantified using simulations that harness a newly-developed geometric framework, which allows one to side-step the highly nonlinear sheet equations in favor of a simple geometric minimization. Experiments study the additional role of gravity and probe the dynamics of a sheet that is propelled by a curvature gradient. The results will uncover new methods for controlling and modifying liquid surfaces with thin films, going beyond what can be accomplished with particle and molecular surfactants. Second, stress-focusing transitions are studied for floating polymer films. It is generally unknown how curvature, tension, and confinement conspire to create sharp stress-focusing features out of smooth wrinkles. A "wrinkle-to-crumple" transition is studied for polymer films in several well-controlled setups including: (i) indentation into a liquid bath, (ii) axial compression on a cylindrically-curved meniscus, and (iii) isotropic compression. The work will shed light on pattern formation and symmetry breaking in nonlinear settings.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to understand and exploit the "geometric frustration" of a thin sheet on a liquid surface with a differing curvature. Mismatches in curvature between two surfaces are a common problem: flat bandages do not conform to knuckles, maps of the earth expand areas near the poles, and automotive metal must be stamped or forged to make curved fenders. This project investigated how such geometric frustration can be turned into something useful, ranging from new fundamental insights into the physics of thin materials, to novel mechanical or optical behaviors that could enable new technologies.

Here we summarize five major scientific discoveries from the project, followed by a list of products produced. We then describe impacts on the training and education of the scientific workforce, and impacts on the general public including a successful high-school teacher internship program.

(1) Wrinkle-to-crumple transition: We discovered a universal "building block" for how elastic films deform when they are squeezed and curved. We found that sharp, localized features occur when smooth wrinkles are curved beyond a threshold that we now understand. Our results tell us when to expect damage in thin materials, such as polymer films, metal foils, or graphene sheets.

(2) Ordered and disordered wrinkle patterns: To address the complexity of wrinkle patterns, we asked the following basic question: "What happens when the direction of wrinkling conflicts with the preferred wavelength of the undulations?" Working with collaborators, we developed a quantitative framework for understanding the organization of groups of wrinkles, with analogs to behaviors in liquid crystals and superconductors.

(3) Sculpting liquids with ultrathin caps: We made extremely thin curved sheets, or "shells" (think of a contact lens but 1,000 times thinner) and asked whether they could sculpt a liquid surface into a desired 3D shape. When laid on a pool of water, a polymer shell forms wrinkles as it clings to the flat liquid bath. We found that the wrinkled region may be inflated into the original spherical shape of the polymer shell. Our results could be useful for optical applications, as the inflated sheets are transparent, smooth, and free of wrinkles.

(4) Predicting the layout of wrinkles: We studied the formation of complex wrinkle patterns when a curved sheet is pressed flat. Working closely with an applied mathematician and theoretical physicist, we showed that all the patterns can be predicted using just two simple rules. These rules could be used to design detailed wrinkle patterns for smart surfaces.

(5) Complex deformations of stiff balloons: We used experiments and simulations to investigate a model system consisting of a thin-membraned balloon, partially filled with water and pressurized with air. Working with a theoretician, we developed a two-dimensional model that captures an array of features seen in the experiments, from the shapes of individual folds to how the complex buckling patterns changes with pressure. Our results establish a route to understand complex film morphologies in nature and industry.

Products: To date, this grant has lead to 8 peer-reviewed publications in top journals including Nature Physics, Physical Review X, Physical Review Letters, and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America. Two of these works were featured on journal covers. Discoveries from this grant have been featured in Quanta Magazine, New Scientist, Physics Today, and APS Physics Magazine. One US non-provisional patent has been filed. Results have also been disseminated in 7 invited conference presentations, 10 seminars and colloquia, and 6 outreach talks to high-school teachers and undergraduates.

Training and education: The projects in this grant provided training for 2 postdocs, 4 graduate students, 5 undergraduates, and 1 high-school student. These students gave 16 oral presentations at national and international conferences, plus additional oral and poster presentations at local venues. Graduate student Monica Ripp won an All-University Doctoral Prize in 2022. Two undergraduate students won NSF Graduate Research Fellowships, and one was selected for the National REU Symposium.

Outreach: Four high-school teachers performed 6-week full-time internships in the PI's lab. They are all sharing these experiences with their students at four schools in Central New York. One teacher is using her experience from this internship to lead a group of teachers in the Jefferson-Lewis Teacher Center to revamp their teaching labs. The PI was also involved in several outreach activities, including presenting the work to high-school teachers in New York City and Syracuse, serving as a panelist in grant writing workshops for junior faculty (once) and the Syracuse University Women in Science and Engineering Postdoc Group (twice), and presenting the work in a Bio-Art Mixer at Syracuse University.
